prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity:
As detailed in the Science Case we request the continuum sensitivity of 0.05 mJy at band 7. This corresponds to ~20 min of integration time on-source per target (depending on the declination) and a total 6.9 hr for 8 sources, including calibration. This was calculated with the OT assuming an average weather condition of precipitable water vapour of 0.658-0.913 mm (2nd-3rd octile).
Imaging requirements:
Our targets have optical sizes <~1". As we plan a detection experiment, we opt for the spatial resolution of ~1" in order not to resolve the targets.
Correlator setup:
We have chosen the band 7 as it gives the best SFR limit for a given integration time compared to other bands. In order to achieve the best possible sensitivity we will use the dual polarisation mode. We selected the continuum mode, as only high-ionisation CO lines, unlikely to be exited in these galaxies, fall into band 7 at the redshifts of our targets.
Calibration: Default
Bandpass accuracy: Standard
Scheduling/time constraints: None
Data rate: Normal
Special constraints on standard observing modes: The proposed targets are GRB hosts, which are spread uniformly on the sky, so in the most of the cases it was not possible to find any other suitable target within <10 deg. This results in significant overheads, but this is the only way to observe these unique extragalactic objects, which were not selected from deep fields (similarly to high-z quasars).
The same as in the first Science Goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are tracers of the cosmic star formation (SF) history, which is of fundamental importance in cosmology. Here we propose the first submm study of GRB hosts which is not biased against dusty systems, in order to critically assess this issue at redshifts of the peak of the SF activity (z=1-2.5). We will compare the fraction of (U)LIRGs among GRB hosts with the infrared luminosity functions to characterize the relation between the GRB rate and the SFR density, as we we will detect most of the eight targets, unless the GRB rate is extremely skewed with respect to dust-obscured SFR. Building on our rich multi-wavelength dataset we will study the relation between dust-enshrouded and UV-visible SF activity to reach the understanding of the interplay between the GRB explosion and the properties of its environment. Hence, we are guaranteed to obtain breakthrough results: either a detection of a significant number of targets, allowing us to study their dust properties and the relation of GRBs to the cosmic SFR, or a firm conclusion that these galaxies have very little dust and therefore that GRBs are biased tracer of the global star-formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00020.S - rejected due to biases in the target selection
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
